what: Adding new Tables, Listing and Graphs
title: Adding new TLGs to the package
text: order add new TLGs, two things needed: - TLG definition specified tlg.yaml file - implementation function responsible generating entry (table, list, graph).

previous_headings: Adding new Tables, Listing and Graphs
title: Adding new TLGs to the package
text: Specified tlg.yaml file. Entry file responsible providing metadata regarding TLG (like name, descriptions, links), function reference creating resulting TLG options, taken arguments generating function, allow quick easy definition widgets rendered application interface. allows user customize plots accordance needs.

previous_headings: Adding new Tables, Listing and Graphs > TLG definition
title: Adding new TLGs to the package
text: entry following format. Identifying keys (wrapped <>) provided creator unique within scope (indentation level).
code: # unique identifier for given entry <entry id>:   # true / false whether TLG should be included as default   is_default:   # type of the TLG, in this case must be Graph   type:   # name of the dataset   dataset:   # standarized id of the TLG, e.g. pkcg01        pkid:   # short label to be displayed as tab name   label:   # longer descriptions, to be displayed in the order table   description:   # link to the documentation of the TLG   link:   # name of the function exported by the package, responsible for generating TLG, must return a list of plots to be displayed   fun:   # options that can be passed as arguments to the function, will generate an editing widget on the TLG page   options:     # see below mor more information on options        template:   # You can also specify template definitions. This is a character string with id of another TLG definition. All options will be copied over from template id. Any provided parameters will be a) overwritten if existing in the template or b) added as new.

title: Build Units Table for PKNCA — PKNCA_build_units_table
text: function performs following steps: Ensures unit columns (e.g., concu, timeu, doseu, amountu) exist inputs. Joins concentration dose data based grouping columns. Generates PKNCA units table group, including conversion factors custom units. Returns unique table relevant columns PKNCA analysis.

title: Build Units Table for PKNCA — PKNCA_build_units_table
code: # Assuming `o_conc` and `o_dose` are valid PKNCA objects: # 1) Sharing group variables in their formulas # 2) Time units are the same within dose groups # 3) Units are the same for subjects within the same concentration group  d_conc <- data.frame(   subj = 1,   analyte = rep(c("A", "B"), each = 2),   concu = rep(c("ng/mL", "ug/mL"), each = 2),   conc = c(0, 2, 0, 5),   time = rep(0:1, 2),   timeu = "h" ) d_dose <- data.frame(   subj = 1,   dose = 100,   doseu = "mg",   time = 0,   timeu = "h" ) o_conc <- PKNCA::PKNCAconc(d_conc, conc ~ time | subj / analyte, concu = "concu") o_dose <- PKNCA::PKNCAdose(d_dose, dose ~ time | subj, doseu = "doseu") units_table <- PKNCA_build_units_table(o_conc, o_dose)

title: Creates a PKNCA::PKNCAdata object. — PKNCA_create_data_object
text: function creates standard PKNCAdata object ADNCA data. requires following columns ADNCA data: STUDYID: Study identifier. PCSPEC: Matrix. ROUTE: Route administration. DOSETRT: Drug identifier. USUBJID: Unique subject identifier. ATPTREF: (Non- standard column). Can column, used filtering data NCA PARAM: Analyte. AVAL: Analysis value. AVALU: AVAL unit. DOSEA: Dose amount. DOSEU: Dose unit. AFRLT: Actual time first dose. ARRLT: Actual time reference dose. NFRLT: Nominal time first dose. ADOSEDUR: Duration dose. RRLTU: Time unit. Creating pk concentration data using format_pkncaconc_data(). Creating dosing data using format_pkncadose_data(). Creating PKNCAconc object using PKNCA::PKNCAconc(). formula AVAL ~ AFRLT | STUDYID + PCSPEC + DOSETRT + USUBJID / PARAM. Creating PKNCAdose object using PKNCA::PKNCAdose(). formula DOSEA ~ AFRLT | STUDYID + DOSETRT + USUBJID. Creating PKNCAdata object using PKNCA::PKNCAdata(). Updating units PKNCAdata object analyte unit.

title: Convert Volume Units to Match Concentration Denominator Units — convert_volume_units
text: modified data frame VOLUME VOLUMEU converted (necessary) multiplying AVAL * VOLUME results unit consistent dimensionality (typically mass moles). new column AMOUNTU created represent product AVALU VOLUMEU.

title: Convert Volume Units to Match Concentration Denominator Units — convert_volume_units
text: uses units package perform unit-safe conversions. direct conversion volume concentration denominator possible (e.g., mass volume), fallback conversion attempted using neutral density 1 (target_unit / original_unit). function modifies VOLUME VOLUMEU columns necessary leaves data unchanged. function: Parses denominator AVALU (e.g., "ug/mL" → "mL"). Attempts convert corresponding VOLUME unit. direct conversion fails, assumes neutral density 1 (.e., 1 unit_target / unit_original) retries. Leaves units unchanged non-excreta samples already-valid combinations. function assumes AVALU column contains concentration units form "x/y" (e.g., "ug/mL", "mg/g").

title: Convert Volume Units to Match Concentration Denominator Units — convert_volume_units
code: df <- data.frame(   PCSPEC = c("urine", "feces", "plasma"),   AVAL = c(100, 5, 70),   AVALU = c("ug/mL", "mg/g", "ng/mL"),   VOLUME = c(2, 1.5, 3),   VOLUMEU = c("L", "mL", "mL"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  df_converted <- convert_volume_units(df) #> Row 1: Converted volume from 2 L to 2000 mL based on concentration unit ug/mL #> Row 2: Converted volume from 1.5 mL to 1.5 g based on concentration unit mg/g

title: Detect study types — detect_study_types
text: data dataset containing study types identified. Assumed output aNCA formatted concentration data. Must contain group columns, specified route, analyte drug columns, ADOSEDUR. groups grouping variables study type detection. metabfl_column character string specifying column name metabolite flag, coded "Y" metabolites route_column character string specifying column name route administration. volume_column character string specifying column name volume sample. Extravascular samples must written extravascular. Can set volume applicable.

title: Detect study types — detect_study_types
text: data frame summarizing detected study types, including grouping columns identified type.

title: Detect study types — detect_study_types
text: function identifies possible five different types studies based grouping STUDYID, DOSETRT, USUBJID, PCSPEC, route column. study types determined follows: "Excretion Data": volume column group NA values > 0. "Single Extravascular Dose": one dose TRTRINT available, route extravascular. "Single IV Infusion Dose": one dose TRTRINT present, route extravascular. "Single IV Bolus Dose": one dose TRTRINT present, route extravascular, ADOSEDUR == 0. "Multiple Extravascular Doses": multiple doses (TRTRINT available) route extravascular. "Multiple IV Infusion Doses": multiple doses (TRTRINT available) route extravascular. "Multiple IV Bolus Doses": multiple doses TRTRINT present, route extravascular, ADOSEDUR == 0. none conditions met, type marker "Unknown".

title: Detect study types — detect_study_types
code: sample_data <- data.frame(   STUDYID = "STUDY001",   DOSETRT = "Drug",   ANALYTE = "DOSETRT",   USUBJID = c(     # 1. Single IV Dose subject     "Subj-01", "Subj-01",     # 2. Multiple Extravascular Doses subject (identified by TRTRINT)     "Subj-02", "Subj-02",     # 3. Excretion Data subject (identified by positive volume)     "Subj-03", "Subj-03"   ),   PCSPEC = "PLASMA",   DOSNOA = c(     1, 1,        # Single dose     1, 1,        # Appears as single dose...     1, 1         # Single dose   ),   ROUTE = c(     "INTRAVENOUS", "INTRAVENOUS",     "extravascular", "extravascular",     "INTRAVENOUS", "INTRAVENOUS"   ),   ADOSEDUR = c(   0, 0,   0, 0,   2, 2),   SAMPLE_VOLUME = c(     NA, 0,     NA, 0,     10, 12       # Positive volume indicates excretion   ),   TRTRINT = c(     NA, NA,     24, 24,      # ...but TRTRINT indicates a multiple-dose regimen     NA, NA   ),   METABFL = c(     "N", "N",     "N", "N",     "Y", "Y"    # mark last subject as metabolite   ) )  study_summary <- detect_study_types(   data = sample_data,   groups = c("USUBJID", "PCSPEC", "DOSETRT"),   metabfl_column = "METABFL",   route_column = "ROUTE",   volume_column = "SAMPLE_VOLUME" )

title: Add specified imputation methods to the intervals in a PKNCAdata or data.frame object. — interval_add_impute
code: d_conc <- data.frame(   conc = c(1, 0.6, 0.2, 0.1, 0.9, 0.4, 1.2, 0.8, 0.3, 0.2, 1.1, 0.5),   time = rep(0:5, 2),   ID = rep(1:2, each = 6),   param = rep(c("Analyte1", "Analyte2"), each = 6) )  d_dose <- data.frame(   dose = c(100, 200),   time = c(0, 0),   ID = c(1, 2) )  o_conc <- PKNCA::PKNCAconc(d_conc, conc ~ time | ID / param) o_dose <- PKNCA::PKNCAdose(d_dose, dose ~ time | ID)  intervals <- data.frame(   start = c(0, 0, 0),   end = c(3, 5, Inf),   half.life = c(TRUE, TRUE, TRUE),   cmax = c(TRUE, TRUE, TRUE),   impute = c("start_conc0,start_predose", "start_predose", "start_conc0"),   param = c("Analyte1", "Analyte2", "Analyte1") )  o_data <- PKNCA::PKNCAdata(o_conc, o_dose, intervals = intervals)  # Apply interval_add_impute function o_data <- interval_add_impute(o_data,                               target_impute = "start_conc0",                               target_params = "half.life",                               target_groups = data.frame(param = "Analyte1"))

title: Create PK Concentration Listing — l_pkcl01
code: # Create a sample dataframe 'data' with the required variables   set.seed(123)   data <- data.frame(     PARAM = rep(c("Param1", "Param2"), each = 6),     PCSPEC = rep(c("Blood", "Urine"), each = 6),     TRT01A = rep(c("Treatment1", "Treatment2"), each = 6),     USUBJID = rep(c(rep(1, 3), rep(2, 3)), 2),     NFRLT = rep(1:3, 4),     AFRLT = rep(1:3, 4) + runif(12, 0, 0.5),     TIMEU = "hours",     AVAL = rep(0:2, 4) + runif(12, 0, 0.5),     AVALU = "mg/L"   )    # Define the formatting table   formatting_vars_table <- data.frame(var_name = names(data),                                       Label = c("Parameter", "Specimen", "Treatment Arm",                                                 "Unique Subject ID", "Norminal Time ($TIMEU)",                                                 "Actual Time ($TIMEU)", "Time Unit",                                                 "Analyte Value ($AVALU)", "Analyte Unit"),                                       na_str = "Missing",                                       zero_str = c(rep("0", 7), "BLQ", "0"),                                       align = "center",                                       format_fun = c(NA, NA, NA, NA,                                                      "round", "round", NA, "round", NA),                                       digits = c(NA, NA, NA, NA, 2, 2, NA, 3, NA))    # Call the l_pkcl01 function with the sample data   listing_ex <- l_pkcl01(data = data,                          listgroup_vars = c("PARAM", "PCSPEC"),                          grouping_vars = c("TRT01A", "USUBJID"),                          displaying_vars = c("NFRLT", "AFRLT", "AVAL"),                          formatting_vars_table = formatting_vars_table,                          title = "Listing of PK Concentration",                          subtitle = "Subjects with !PARAM: $PARAM (!PCSPEC: $PCSPEC)"                          )   print(listing_ex) #> $Param1.Blood #> Listing of PK Concentration #> Subjects with Parameter: Param1 (Specimen: Blood) #>  #> —————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————— #> Treatment Arm   Unique Subject ID   Norminal Time (hours)   Actual metadata_nca_variables — metadata_nca_variables
text: data frame 361 rows 14 variables: Dataset Character. Indicates dataset variable belongs (PP, ADNCA, ADPP). Order Numeric. Variable order within domain, based Role, Core Variable Variable Character. short name variable. Label Character. descriptive label variable. Type Character. Data type variable (Char, Num, text, integer, float, dateTime). Role Character. CDISC role variable (e.g., Identifier, Topic, Timing...). Core Character. Indicates core status variable (Req = Required, Perm = Permissible, Exp = Expected, Cond = Conditional). company_specific Logical. Indicates variable company-specific (CDISC). .core Logical. TRUE variable core variable (always needed present). Length Numeric. maximum length variable. Controlled_Terms Character. Reference controlled terminology (e.g., C85839, C66731). .used Logical. TRUE variable meant included. Values Character. Possible values (applicable) variable separated ', '. .mapped Logical. TRUE variable mapped ADNCA (App's input). mapping_tooltip Character. Tooltip text mapping guidance App. mapping_section Character. Mapping section variable classified App. mapping_alternatives Character. Alternative column names variable. mapping_order Numeric. Defines mapped variables order mapped dataset
